results.title: Kim’s Video Is Back. What Even Is a Video Store in 2022?
results.abstract: Alamo Drafthouse bought the seminal New York chain’s collection in an effort to make rentals a draw for moviegoers. Can one disrupted business help another?
results.byline: By Gabe Cohn and Adam Powell

multimedia.caption: The boxes and videos were separated at the original Kim’s. The Alamo team matched them up again.

results.title: Caleb Landry Jones Can Do This
results.abstract: The actor — whose latest film, the Australian drama “Nitram,” earned him a top prize at Cannes — discusses his distinctive career in challenging roles.

results.title: ‘Morbius’ Review: The Other Bat, Man
results.abstract: Jared Leto bares his teeth as a neo-vampire who walks by day and tries to keep his monstrous thirst at bay in the latest Marvel adaptation.

results.title: Russia and Ukraine Have Long Been This Filmmaker’s Subject
results.abstract: In documentaries and fictional features, including two timely new movies, Sergei Loznitsa takes a hard look at both countries, examining daily life amid war and other historic forces.

results.title: Will Smith Resigns From Academy After Slapping Chris Rock at Oscars
results.abstract: The producer of the telecast said that Smith had been asked to leave after slapping Rock, and that he had urged officials not to “physically remove” him.
results.byline: By Nicole Sperling and Matt Stevens

results.title: ‘Babi Yar: Context’ Review: Unearthing Footage of a Nazi Massacre
results.abstract: Sergei Loznitsa’s new documentary, about the mass murder of Ukrainian Jews in 1941, arrives in theaters with a grim context of its own.
des_facet: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

multimedia.caption: Sergei Loznitsa’s new documentary “Babi Yar: Context,” about a Nazi-led massacre in Ukraine, is made from footage Germans and Soviets recorded of their campaigns there.

results.title: Using Film to Tell a Personal History of America and Race
results.abstract: With “Who We Are,” the lecturer Jeffery Robinson and the directors Emily and Sarah Kunstler follow in the tradition of documentaries that excavate our past.
des_facet: Who We Are: A Chronicle of Racism in America (Movie)

results.title: Jerrod Carmichael Comes Out in a Riveting Special That’s About So Much More
results.abstract: In “Rothaniel” on HBO, the stand-up grapples with secrets that defined his upbringing, the toll silence has taken and the price he’s paying to break it.

results.title: ‘The Bubble’ Review: Swabs, Camera, Action
results.abstract: Judd Apatow’s new film is a comedy about actors trying to make a dinosaur movie during the pandemic that plays more like a documentary of actors trying to make a Covid comedy.

results.title: Paul Herman, Mainstay of Gangster Movies, Is Dead at 76
results.abstract: Over a four-decade career, he was perhaps best known for his role on “The Sopranos.” But he also had dozens of film credits, including “Goodfellas” and “The Irishman.”
results.byline: By Mike Ives and Alex Traub

results.title: A Filmmaker’s Journey to the Center of Celine Dion
results.abstract: In her kooky, rambunctious biopic “Aline,” the French comedian Valérie Lemercier drew from her own life to play the Quebecois pop star at every stage of hers.

multimedia.caption: Valérie Lemercier even plays a 5-year-old version of Celine Dion in her film “Aline.” “Little girls, more than little boys, fascinate me — what they say, what they imagine, what goes on in their mind.”

results.title: Bruce Willis Has Aphasia and Is ‘Stepping Away’ From His Career
results.abstract: The news of his diagnosis, initially announced by his ex-wife, Demi Moore, prompted an outpouring of support and appreciation for Willis from fans, stars and other notable figures.

results.title: Representation or Stereotype? Deaf Viewers Are Torn Over ‘CODA’
results.abstract: They’re hesitant to criticize the Oscar-winning film because it showcases deaf actors and lives, but some find its hearing perspective frustrating or even upsetting.

multimedia.caption: Emilia Jones (with Eugenio Derbez at the piano) plays a hearing teenager whose desire to sing confounds her family. Critics say they are confounded by the film’s depiction of the relationship between deafness and music.

results.title: When the Master of the Erotic Thriller Fails to Thrill
results.abstract: Adrian Lyne used to make deranged romps animated by conservative masculine anxieties. By the time of “Deep Water,” his muse — the all-powerful white man — had lost his grip.

multimedia.caption: “Deep Water,” starring Ana de Armas and Ben Affleck and directed by the master of the erotic thriller, Adrian Lyne, proves neither erotic nor thrilling.

results.title: ‘How to Survive a Pandemic’ Review: Racing for a Shot
results.abstract: The director David France’s new documentary, about the global effort to develop and disseminate vaccines for the coronavirus, inspires striking candor from some of its subjects.
